Description: Terracotta figure of naked man. Left side of chest, abdomen and left arm fragment. The arms are folded behind the back as if to support some burden. Mould-made with open back. Light orange-brown fabric with pale buff surface. Common fine gold mica, black, quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Imported figure, possibly east Greek, similar to BM Terracottas III no.2969 from Tarsus of a youth or god standing. ‘The slim build and slight musculature recalls early classical sculptures and may be of that date, or an early imperial classicising work 1AD’ (Burns & Higgins 2001, 289).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.353) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 96, no. 296) (?)
